messages.content:
You are a professional academic reference prediction expert. Your task is to predict the most likely references for a given academic paper based on its title, abstract, and retrieved relevant papers.

RETRIEVER INTERFACE:
- Input: paper title + abstract
- Output: {top_r} retrieved papers with title and abstract
- Format: List of dictionaries with 'title' and 'abstract' fields

REQUIREMENTS:
1. Analyze the paper's title and abstract to understand its research area and focus
2. Consider the retrieved papers as potential references (when available)
3. Generate a list of predicted reference titles that would be most relevant and likely to be cited
4. Provide reasoning for each prediction to prevent hallucination
5. Output format: JSON object with "titles" array and "reasoning" string
6. Generate exactly 48 most relevant reference titles (this should be at least 40 to cover all evaluation metrics)
7. Ensure titles are realistic and appropriate for the research area
8. Consider citation patterns in the field
9. CRITICAL: Each title must be unique - never repeat the same title multiple times

EXAMPLE:
Input:
Title: "Question Type Classification Methods Comparison"
Abstract: "The paper presents a comparative study of state-of-the-art approaches for question classification task: Logistic Regression, Convolutional Neural Networks (CNN), Long Short-Term Memory Network (LSTM) and Quasi-Recurrent Neural Networks (QRNN). All models use pre-trained GLoVe word embeddings and trained on human-labeled data. The best accuracy is achieved using CNN model with five convolutional layers and various kernel sizes stacked in parallel, followed by one fully connected layer. The model reached 90.7% accuracy on TREC 10 test set."

Retrieved papers ({top_r}):
1. Title: Convolutional Neural Networks for Sentence Classification
   Abstract: We report on a series of experiments with convolutional neural networks trained on top of pre-trained word vectors for sentence-level classification tasks.

2. Title: Glove: Global vectors for word representation
   Abstract: We present a new global log-bilinear regression model that combines the advantages of the two major model families in the literature.

Output:
{
  "titles": [
    "Convolutional Neural Networks for Sentence Classification",
    "Glove: Global vectors for word representation",
    "Quasi-Recurrent Neural Networks",
    "A Comparative Study of Neural Network Models for Sentence Classification",
    "Deep lstm based feature mapping for query classification"
  ],
  "reasoning": "Based on the paper's focus on question classification using neural networks, I predict these references because: 1) CNN paper is directly relevant to the convolutional approach used; 2) GloVe embeddings are mentioned as pre-trained features; 3) QRNN is one of the compared methods; 4) Comparative study papers are common in this field; 5) LSTM-based query classification is closely related to question classification. Additional references cover related neural network architectures, NLP applications, deep learning methodologies, optimization techniques, and advanced neural network methods that would be relevant for this research area."
}

Return JSON object only.

Paper Title: Hardness Results for Laplacians of Simplicial Complexes via Sparse-Linear Equation Complete Gadgets

Paper Abstract: Abstract We study linear equations in combinatorial Laplacians of kùëòk-dimensional simplicial complexes (kùëòk-complexes), a natural generalization of graph Laplacians. Combinatorial Laplacians play a crucial role in homology and are a central tool in topology. Beyond this, they have various applications in data analysis and physical modeling problems. It is known that nearly-linear time solvers exist for graph Laplacians. However, nearly-linear time solvers for combinatorial Laplacians are only known for restricted classes of complexes. This paper shows that linear equations in combinatorial Laplacians of 2-complexes are as hard to solve as general linear equations. More precisely, for any constant c‚â•1ùëê1c\geq 1, if we can solve linear equations in combinatorial Laplacians of 2-complexes up to high accuracy in time O~‚Äã((#‚Äã of nonzero coefficients)c)~ùëÇsuperscript# of nonzero coefficientsùëê\tilde{O}((\#\text{ of nonzero coefficients})^{c}), then we can solve general linear equations with polynomially bounded integer coefficients and condition numbers up to high accuracy in time O~‚Äã((#‚Äã of nonzero coefficients)c)~ùëÇsuperscript# of nonzero coefficientsùëê\tilde{O}((\#\text{ of nonzero coefficients})^{c}). We prove this by a nearly-linear time reduction from general linear equations to combinatorial Laplacians of 2-complexes. Our reduction preserves the sparsity of the problem instances up to poly-logarithmic factors.

{retrieved_text}

Generate exactly 48 most likely reference titles for this paper. Focus on papers that are directly related to the research topic, provide foundational background, present similar methodologies, or address related problems.

CRITICAL: Each title must appear exactly once. Do not repeat any title.

IMPORTANT: You must respond with ONLY valid JSON in this exact format:
{
    "titles": [
        "Reference Title 1",
        "Reference Title 2",
        "Reference Title 3",
        "Reference Title 4",
        "Reference Title 48"
    ],
    "reasoning": "Explain why you chose these specific references based on the paper's title, abstract, and retrieved papers. This helps prevent hallucination and ensures relevance."
}

Do not include any text before or after the JSON. Do not include authors, venues, or years - only the paper titles. The reasoning field is required to explain your prediction logic.

{
    "titles": [
        "A refined laser method and faster matrix multiplication",
        "Solving elliptic finite element systems in near-linear time with support preconditioners",
        "Computational Topology in a Collapsing Universe: Laplacians, Homology, Cohomology",
        "Optimal Fine-Grained Hardness of Approximation of Linear Equations",
        "Topology and Data",
        "The Structure and Stability of Persistence Modules",
        "Representation of functions on big data associated with directed graphs",
        "Solving 1-laplacians in nearly linear time: Collapsing and expanding a topological ball",
        "Solving SDD linear systems in nearly m log 1/2 n time",
        "Almost-linear-time Algorithms for Markov Chains and New Spectral Primitives for Directed Graphs",
        "Solving directed laplacian systems in nearly-linear time through sparse LU factorizations",
        "Simplicial matrix-tree theorems",
        "Cuts and flows of cell complexes",
        "Discrete differential forms for computational modeling",
        "Support-graph preconditioners for 2-dimensional trusses",
        "Combinatorial Laplacian of the matching complex",
        "Harmonische funktionen und randwertaufgaben in einem komplex",
        "Computational Topology: An Introduction",
        "Computing Betti numbers via combinatorial Laplacians",
        "Barcodes: The Persistent Topology of Data",
        "Algebraic topology",
        "Methods of conjugate gradients for solving linear systems",
        "Statistical ranking and combinatorial Hodge theory",
        "Ultrasparse Ultrasparsifiers and Faster Laplacian System Solvers",
        "Approaching Optimality for Solving SDD Linear Systems",
        "A Nearly-m Log n Time Solver for Sdd Linear Systems",
        "Combinatorial preconditioners and multilevel solvers for problems in computer vision and image processing",
        "Approximate Gaussian Elimination for Laplacians-Fast, Sparse, and Simple",
        "Packing LPs Are Hard to Solve Accurately, Assuming Linear Equations Are Hard",
        "Sparsified Cholesky and Multigrid Solvers for Connection Laplacians",
        "Incomplete nested dissection",
        "Hardness results for structured linear systems",
        "Hodge laplacians on graphs",
        "An L 1-based variational model for Retinex theory and its application to medical images",
        "Computing maximum flow with augmenting electrical flows",
        "Generalized max-flows and min-cuts in simplicial complexes",
        "Elements of algebraic topology",
        "Matrix anti-concentration inequalities with applications",
        "An Efficient Parallel Solver for SDD Linear Systems",
        "Solving sparse linear systems faster than matrix multiplication",
        "A mathematical view of interior-point methods in convex optimization",
        "Random walks on simplicial complexes and the normalized hodge 1-laplacian",
        "Nearly linear time algorithms for preconditioning and solving symmetric, diagonally dominant linear systems",
        "Gaussian Elimination Is Not Optimal",
        "Discrete multiscale vector field decomposition",
        "HodgeRank on random graphs for subjective video quality assessment",
        "Cohomology of cryo-electron microscopy",
        "Topology for Computing"
    ],
    "reasoning": "Selected these 48 references because they represent foundational work and recent advances in Hardness Results for Laplacians of Simplicial Complexes via Sparse-Linear Equation Complete Gadgets, providing essential background knowledge and methodological foundations relevant to this research."
}
